title: Detecting Fake News with TF-IDF and Machine Learning
text:
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

title: Detecting Fake News with TF-IDF and Machine Learning
text:
Goal
My goal is to develop a transparent and accurate machine learning model that can classify news articles as fake or real based on their textual content and identify the words or phrases most predictive of fake news.

title: Detecting Fake News with TF-IDF and Machine Learning
text:
Dataset

fake_real_news = pd.read_csv("data/fake_or_real_news_data.csv")

# Rename unnamed column
fake_real_news.rename(columns={"Unnamed: 0": "article #"}, inplace=True)

# Print column names
display(fake_real_news.columns)

# Print data types & shape of data
display(fake_real_news.info())

Index(['article #', 'title', 'text', 'label'], dtype='object')


<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
RangeIndex: 6335 entries, 0 to 6334
Data columns (total 4 columns):
 #   Column     Non-Null Count  Dtype 
---  ------     --------------  ----- 
 0   article #  6335 non-null   int64 
 1   title      6335 non-null   object
 2   text       6335 non-null   object
 3   label      6335 non-null   object
dtypes: int64(1), object(3)
memory usage: 198.1+ KB


None


The dataset I am using for the project is the Fake and Real News Dataset from Kaggle. It consists of roughly 6,300 rows with four columns representing article title, text content, and label (fake or real). I will combine the title and text for a comprehensive representation; this dataset is appropriate for the project because it provides balanced and diverse examples of fake and real news. I chose this dataset because it includes the full details of articles and it’s also large enough to train the model and make predictions.

title: Detecting Fake News with TF-IDF and Machine Learning
text:
Questions
Can we build an effective and interpretable fake news classifier using TF-IDF and machine learning?
Can we identify which words or phrases are most predictive of fake news content using categorical features?

from textblob import TextBlob

# Function to get sentiment scores
def get_sentiment(text):
    blob = TextBlob(str(text))  # Ensure it's a string
    return pd.Series([blob.sentiment.polarity, 
                      blob.sentiment.subjectivity])

# Title sentiment features
fake_real_news[['title_polarity', 
                'title_subjectivity']] = fake_real_news['title'].apply(get_sentiment)

# Text sentiment features
fake_real_news[['text_polarity', 
                'text_subjectivity']] = fake_real_news['text'].apply(get_sentiment)

# Preview the new dataset with sentiment features
fake_real_news.head()

title: Detecting Fake News with TF-IDF and Machine Learning
text:
Feature Engineering







Feature
Description




title_polarity
Sentiment score of the title from -1 (negative) to +1 (positive)


title_subjectivity
Subjectivity score of the title from 0 (objective) to 1 (subjective)


text_polarity
Sentiment score of the full text from -1 (negative) to +1 (positive)


text_subjectivity
Subjectivity score of the full text from 0 (objective) to 1 (subjective)

title: Detecting Fake News with TF-IDF and Machine Learning
text:
Analysis plan

First, I will preprocess the data and apply TF-IDF to extract relevant textual features.
Next, I will train machine learning classifiers and evaluate their performance to assess effectiveness.
Finally, I will interpret the model to identify which words or patterns most strongly predict fake news.

title: Detecting Fake News with TF-IDF and Machine Learning
text:
Weekly Plan







Week
Task




1
Data loading, cleaning, preprocessing, and exploratory data analysis. Implement TF-IDF vectorization and basic logistic regression model.


2
Model training, hyperparameter tuning, and evaluation. Extract top predictive words/phrases using model coefficients. Begin documentation of results.


3
Prepare final analysis and visualizations of predictive words. Write up project report, finalize README files, and organize code repository structure.

title: Detecting Fake News with TF-IDF and Machine Learning
text: Recently, fake news has been spreading a lot globally, which really questions the credibility and trustworthiness of the news source. In order to stop falling for the fake news, we must check the news source and make sure it is credible, and also read the news article thoroughly to see if it makes sense.

title: Project title
text:
Math Expressions
You can write LaTeX math expressions inside a pair of dollar signs, e.g. $\alpha+\beta$ renders \(\alpha + \beta\). You can use the display style with double dollar signs:
$$\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i$$
\[
\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i
\]
Limitations:

The source code of a LaTeX math expression must be in one line, unless it is inside a pair of double dollar signs, in which case the starting $$ must appear in the very beginning of a line, followed immediately by a non-space character, and the ending $$ must be at the end of a line, led by a non-space character;
There should not be spaces after the opening $ or before the closing $.

title: Project title
text:
Feeling adventurous?

You are welcomed to use the default styling of the slides. In fact, that’s what I expect majority of you will do. You will differentiate yourself with the content of your presentation.
But some of you might want to play around with slide styling. Some solutions for this can be found at https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/revealjs.
